title: Tidyverse II: Transform, and visualize
text:
Next: Group & summarize
So far:

We can generate new variables using mutate() keeping the structure of the data the same

With summarize():

we change the structure of our data frame;
any computations using summarize() collapses rows to summary statistics (e.g., mean, standard deviation);
and removes all variables irrelevant for computing the summary statistics.

title: Tidyverse II: Transform, and visualize
text:
Example: Summary statistics - mutate()

afd_mean <- afd %>% 
  filter(vote == 2) %>% 
  mutate(mean = mean(vote_share))

dim(afd)

[1] 598   7

dim(afd_mean)

[1] 299   8

head(afd_mean)

# A tibble: 6 √ó 8
  district_no district_type district_name group_type group_name  vote vote_share
  <chr>       <chr>         <chr>         <chr>      <chr>      <dbl>      <dbl>
1 001         Wahlkreis     Flensburg ‚Äì ‚Ä¶ Partei     AfD            2       15.3
2 002         Wahlkreis     Nordfrieslan‚Ä¶ Partei     AfD            2       16.1
3 003         Wahlkreis     Steinburg ‚Äì ‚Ä¶ Partei     AfD            2       20.4
4 004         Wahlkreis     Rendsburg-Ec‚Ä¶ Partei     AfD            2       16.0
5 005         Wahlkreis     Kiel          Partei     AfD            2       10.8
6 006         Wahlkreis     Pl√∂n ‚Äì Neum√º‚Ä¶ Partei     AfD            2       18.0
# ‚Ñπ 1 more variable: mean <dbl>

title: Tidyverse II: Transform, and visualize
text:
Summarize()

afd_mean <- afd %>% 
  filter(vote == 2) %>% 
  summarize(mean = mean(vote_share)) # option: "na.rm = TRUE"

afd_mean

# A tibble: 1 √ó 1
   mean
  <dbl>
1  21.1

title: Tidyverse II: Transform, and visualize
text:
Summarize()

afd_statistics <- afd %>% 
  filter(vote == 2) %>% 
  summarize(mean = mean(vote_share),      # option: "na.rm = TRUE"
            median = median(vote_share),
            minimum = min(vote_share),
            maximum = max(vote_share),
            sd = sd(vote_share)) 

afd_statistics

# A tibble: 1 √ó 5
   mean median minimum maximum    sd
  <dbl>  <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl> <dbl>
1  21.1   19.4    6.28    46.7  8.50

title: Tidyverse II: Transform, and visualize
text:
Group and summarize
We can use group_by() to calculate summary statistics for different groups:

statistics_group <- election %>% 
  filter(district_type == "Wahlkreis") %>% 
  filter(vote == 2) %>% 
  # this is the same as: filter(group_name == "SPD" | group_name == "CDU")
  filter(group_name %in% c("SPD", "CDU")) %>% 
  group_by(group_name) %>%  # do not forget to ungroup()
  summarize(mean = mean(vote_share,
                        na.rm = TRUE)) %>% 
  ungroup() # ungroup after

statistics_group

# A tibble: 2 √ó 2
  group_name  mean
  <chr>      <dbl>
1 CDU         26.8
2 SPD         16.5

title: Tidyverse II: Transform, and visualize
text:
Join data
In applied research, we oftentimes need to combine multiple data sets (e.g., multiple survey waves, election statistics, ‚Ä¶).

We can use bind_cols() if two (or more) data frames have different variables (columns) but same cases (rows).
We can use bind_rows() if two (or more) data frames have the same variables (columns) but different cases (rows).

We can also use join operators from the dplyr package. These allow us to combine data frames based on a (shared) key.

title: Tidyverse II: Transform, and visualize
text:
Binding columns

Data 1Data 2bind_cols



# Let's use our gapminder_example data
library(gapminder)

gapminder_example <- gapminder

text:
Save your data
We can easily save our data frame:

save(election_structural,
     file="election_structural.Rda")

And load it again:

# make sure that you are in the right working directory!

title: Tidyverse II: Transform, and visualize
text:
Join data frames: left_join()
Other joins: https://github.com/gadenbuie/tidyexplain










1, 2, 3, and 4 are unique identifiers in this case. What might be unique identifiers in our 2025 election results data set?

title: Tidyverse II: Transform, and visualize
text:
Example: left_join()

ElectionStructuralJoin



election <- readr::read_delim("https://www.bundeswahlleiterin.de/bundestagswahlen/2025/ergebnisse/opendata/btw25/csv/kerg2.csv", 
                       delim = ";", 
                       locale = locale(decimal_mark = ","), 
                       skip = 9) %>% 
  dplyr::select(district_no = Gebietsnummer, district_type = Gebietsart, district_name = Gebietsname,
                group_type = Gruppenart, group_name = Gruppenname,
                vote = Stimme, vote_share = Prozent) %>% 
  filter(district_type == "Wahlkreis" & group_name == "AfD" & vote == 2) %>% 
  mutate(district_no = as.numeric(district_no))

head(election, n = 3)

                                delim = ";", escape_double = FALSE,
                                locale = locale(decimal_mark = ","),
                                trim_ws = TRUE, skip = 9) %>% 
  # we need quotation marks since the colum names include - and spaces
  dplyr::select(district_no = "Wahlkreis-Nr.",
                district_name = "Wahlkreis-Name",
                unemployment_rate = "Arbeitslosenquote November 2024 - insgesamt") %>%

title: ggplot: Visualize
text: The datasaurus dozen

title: ggplot: Visualize
text:
What makes a great visualization?
Five qualities of a great visualization according to Cairo:


Truthful - Based on thorough and honest research




Functional - Accurate depiction of the data




Beautiful - Aesthetically pleasing for its intended audience




Insightful - Communicate new evidence




Enlightening - Change your audience‚Äôs mind

title: ggplot: Visualize
text:
What makes a great visualization?
Qualities of a great visualization according to Hiely:

AestheticsSubstancePerceptionHonesty

title: ggplot: Visualize
text: How about this?

title: ggplot: Visualize
text: And this?

title: ggplot: Visualize
text:
What makes a great visualization?
Graphical excellence is the well-designed presentation of interesting data‚Äîa matter of substance, of statistics, and of design ‚Ä¶ [It] consists of complex ideas communicated with clarity, precision, and efficiency. ‚Ä¶ [It] is that which gives to the viewer the greatest number of ideas in the shortest time with the least ink in the smallest space ‚Ä¶ [It] is nearly always multivariate ‚Ä¶ And graphical excellence requires telling the truth about the data.¬†

Edward Tufte (1983). The Visual Display of Quantitative Information, p.¬†51.

title: ggplot: Visualize
text:
Design prinicples
Why would we care about design principles? What is our goal?


Communicating our data in different forms to specific audiences.
Following design principles, we can fulfill the criteria of great visualizations.

title: ggplot: Visualize
text:
Contrast


We want to contrast various elements to get a reader‚Äôs attention.

It creates a hierarchy among different elements of your graph making it more interesting.
However, contrast must be strong!

title: ggplot: Visualize
text:
Repetition


We want to repeat design aspects throughout the graph for consistency.

Elements might include bullet points, typefaces, lines, colors, ‚Ä¶
Repetition makes it easier for a reader to recognize patterns and capture the graph‚Äôs message.

title: ggplot: Visualize
text:
Alignment


We want to align the elements of our graph.

To keep our graph consistent, align every object with an edge of any other object.
Strong alignments allow you to break them occasionally to make a point without making it look like a mistake.

title: ggplot: Visualize
text:
Proximity


We want to group together related elements of our graph.

Group elements into closer proximity if they are related.
Separate elements that are not directly related.
Vary space between groups and elements.

title: ggplot: Visualize
text:
Grammar of graphics
In general:

ggplot(data = DATA) +
  GEOM_FUNCTION(mapping = aes(AESTHETIC MAPPINGS))

For our Gapminder data:

ggplot(data = gapminder) +
  geom_point(mapping = aes(x = gdpPercap,
                           y = lifeExp,
                           color = continent))

In generalStructureFinding shapefiles





Geographic information is shared as shapefiles
They are not the same as regular CSV files
Normally, you download them as zipped files (the .shp ending indicates the relevant file)

title: ggplot: Visualize

CodePlot - 2017 constituencies


If we have a geometry column, all we need to do is use geom_sf():

ggplot(data = constituency_shapes) +
  geom_sf()

title: ggplot: Visualize
text:
Making a choropleth map

And now?CodePlot



From here, it is easy to create a choropleth map.
We just have to add data to our constituency_shapes dataframe.

Remember the election and structural data from the German federal election officer?

And we can use all typical ggplot functions!




constituency_shapes_vote <- constituency_shapes %>% 
  # here, we can use our "btw17_election" data from earlier sessions!
  left_join(btw17_election, by = c("WKR_NR" = "constituency_number")) %>% 
  filter(party == "AfD")

ggplot(data = constituency_shapes_vote,
       aes(fill = vote_share)) +  
  geom_sf() + 
  scale_fill_gradient(low = "lightblue", high = "darkblue") +
  labs(fill = "AfD vote share") +
  theme_void()

title: Space
text:
Where to find projections
You can find projection codes here:

Spatial reference list, epsg.io, and PROJ.org

This lesson by the Earth Lab provides a great overview of different projection formats.
In general, there are no good or bad projections!

It always depends on our data and visualization goals.
For example, the Mercator projection can be a good choice for mapping small areas.

title: Designing a Graph
text:
Design prinicples
Why would we care about design principles? What is our goal?
. . .

Communicating our data in different forms to specific audiences.
Following design principles, we can fulfill the criteria of great visualizations.

title: Designing a Graph
text:
CRAP



Contrast
Repetition
Alignment
Proximity

These design principles apply in all areas of life: Art, architecture, ‚Ä¶, and graphs.

title: Designing a Graph
text:
Contrast


We want to contrast various elements to get a reader‚Äôs attention.

It creates a hierarchy among different elements of your graph making it more interesting.
However, contrast must be strong!

title: Designing a Graph
text:
Repetition


We want to repeat design aspects throughout the graph for consistency.

Elements might include bullet points, typefaces, lines, colors, ‚Ä¶
Repetition makes it easier for a reader to recognize patterns and capture the graph‚Äôs message.

title: Designing a Graph
text:
Alignment


We want to align the elements of our graph.

To keep our graph consistent, align every object with an edge of any other object.
Strong alignments allow you to break them occasionally to make a point without making it look like a mistake.

title: Designing a Graph
text:
Proximity


We want to group together related elements of our graph.

Group elements into closer proximity if they are related.
Separate elements that are not directly related.
Vary space between groups and elements.

Reproducibility ‚ü∂ Why R?
‚Ä¶ and not just Excel? R ‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶ can deal with more data faster.
‚Ä¶ is open-source and free.
‚Ä¶ allows us to reproduce results and understand data processing steps.

title: Quarto
text: But what could go wrong?

title: Quarto
text: ‚Ä¶ a lot!

title: Quarto
text:
‚Ä¶ and there is more ‚Ä¶


Result: Economic growth slows when a country‚Äôs debt is higher than 90% of GDP
Implication: e.g., cited by Republican Paul Ryan in his¬†proposed 2013 budget: The Path to Prosperity: A Blueprint for American Renewal

title: Quarto
text: ‚Ä¶ wrong basis for policy decisions

title: Quarto
text:
How can we avoid this?

Do not change the raw data!

If there is no other way, document and explain what you did extensively.

Use open formats

e.g., .csv and not .xlsx

Use reproducible code

R Markdown & Quarto

title: Quarto
text:
R Markdown
R Markdown provides an unified authoring framework for data science, combining your code, its results, and your prose commentary. R Markdown documents are fully reproducible and support dozens of output formats, like PDFs, Word files, slideshows, and more.
R for Data Science

title: Quarto
section: Why should we use R Markdown?
text:
Why should we use R Markdown?

Communication of our analysis with a focus on conclusions and not on the code.
Collaboration with other researchers who want to understand your data analysis and your code.
Annotation of the codes and thoughts regarding the coding and data analysis can be stored in the same document.

R for Data Science

Moving to Quarto

Quarto is not an R package as R Markdown, but an command line interface tool.
It gives you the same functionality as R Markdown as well as other packages.
It extends R Markdown through native support for other programming languages such as Python.
The ‚Äúnew‚Äù way to produce articles & reports, presentations, interactive documents, websites or books.

title: Version control (Github)
section: Version control in the research workflow
text: Version control in the research workflow

title: Version control (Github)
section: Why should we use version control?
text:
Why should we use version control?

Good academic work entails organisation, and the recording and disseminating of it
Collaboration is much more structured and transparent with version control in place
Git and GitHub can be used for many things:

project management, saving code and outputs
hosting a personal or professional website

Rewarding: You can trace your work and accomplishments

title: Version control (Github)
text:
Git

Git is a version control system. Original purpose: help groups of developers work collaboratively on big software projects
Git manages the evolution of a set of files (called a repository or repo) in a highly structured way
Think of it as the ‚ÄúTrack Changes‚Äù feature from Microsoft Word, but more rigorous, powerful, and scaled up to multiple files
Resources: Overview of basic Git commands & Book on Git: Chacon and Straub (2014)

title: Version control (Github)
text:
Github

GitHub complements Git by providing a polished user interface and distribution mechanism for Git repositories

Git: software you will use locally to record changes to a set of files
GitHub: a hosting service for such projects.

Many operations can be done entirely in the browser
GitHub also offers granular control over who can see, edit, and administer a project
You can apply for a free GitHub Pro account for students!

title: Version control (Github)
text:
Username. Who cares?

Incorporate your actual name in your username!
Reuse your username from other contexts, e.g., Twitter (‚Äúprofessional‚Äù social media)
Pick a (short) username you will be comfortable revealing in applications.
Don‚Äôt highlight your current university, employer, or place of residence
More info & tips

title: Version control (Github)
section: How you could build your profile
text: How you could build your profile

title: Version control (Github)
text:
Terms

Repository/Repo: directory of files that Git manages holistically



Commit: a snapshot of all the files in the repo, at a specific moment. Under the hood, that is not exactly how Git implements things
Commit message: every time you make a commit you must also write a short commit message
Pull request: submitting contributions to a project
Branch: diverge from the main line of development and continue to do work without messing with that main line
For more information see: https://git-scm.com/doc

title: Version control (Github)
text: GitHub workflow

title: Version control (Github)
text:
Setup: How to get started

Register for a free account with GitHub
Install Git. Depending on your OS, Git might already be installed. Usually, you will need to install it or update it to a more recent version
Install a local Git client (e.g., SourceTree, GitKraken, GitHub Desktop). A Git client provides a graphical user interface for Git, which is otherwise command-line only. We will use GitHub Desktop.

‚Üí Once this setup is done, you are ready to start using Git and GitHub

title: Version control (Github)
text:
How to structure your project?

Have a local folder for all of your projects that you want to host on GitHub
For example:

GitHub

bachelor-thesis
seminar_x
seminar_y


You can set up new repositories at github.com or via GitHub Desktop

title: Version control (Github)
text:
What should we commit?
Source files: These files are created and edited by hand, such as R or Python scripts, R Markdown or LaTeX files. This could also include the raw data for an analysis.
Configuration files: These files modify the behavior of a tool, for example .gitignore (identify files or file formats that should not be committed)
Derived products: These files are programmatically generated from source files and have external value. By executing .R or rendering .Rmd files, you obtain artifacts such as intermediate data (e.g., .csv or .rds), figures (e.g., .png or .pdf), and reports (e.g., .md, .pdf, .docx, or .html)

title: Version control (Github)
text:
What not to commit?

Rule of thumb: a file (e.g., intermediate data) that is large and changing often can make your repository bloated and slow down pushes and pulls (speaking from experience!)
You can exclude files from commits by adding it to the .gitignore file

title: Version control (Github)
text: .gitignore

title: Version control (Github)
text:
How to commit changes
Let‚Äôs start by creating a new R script:

library(tidyverse)
library(gapminder)

gapminder %>% 
  filter(year == 2007) %>% 
ggplot(aes(x = gdpPercap,
           y = lifeExp)) +
  geom_point()

title: Version control (Github)
text:
Pushing changes

When you made the commits, we can ‚Äúpush‚Äù these changes to GitHub

(If necessary) publish the repository (top-right corner of GitHub Desktop)
Press the same button (‚ÄúPush origin‚Äù)
Go to github.com, log into your account and look for the repository. Can you see the repository and the changes?

title: Version control (Github)
text: Push changes in GitHub Desktop

title: Version control (Github)
text: Our progress so far:

title: Version control (Github)
text:
Branches

So far, we only used the main branch. But you can commit, push, and pull to more than one branch
A branch is an independent line of development within a repo, where the intent is usually to merge it into the main branch when ready.
You can make edits in a separate branch and test what works. When you are happy with the changes, you can commit to this branch.
Make sure you are in the desired branch when working on your project!

title: Version control (Github)
text:
Pull requests

A pull request is a GitHub-specific way to propose changes to a repo that overlays Git‚Äôs regular branch and merge workflow with facilities for structured review.
A pull request can be made between two branches in the same repo, such as main
Especially useful/necessary in collaborative projects
Also useful if you experiment and change code in your personal project

title: Version control (Github)
text: Branches and pull requests

title: Version control (Github)
text:
Live coding

how to create a new branch
how to make changes in this branch
how to publish the branch
how to make a pull request
how to merge a pull request

title: Version control (Github)
text:
Conflicts

Conflicts occur when there are competing line changes in two branches
Common in collaborative projects
Requires time and effort but makes sure that everyone involved knows what has been changed
How to handle conflicts is beyond the scope of today‚Äôs session but see: resolving a merge conflict on GitHub

title: Version control (Github)
text:
Take aways

Version control is important & can be motivating and rewarding
Reproducible research is key and required for most journals
Allows you to go ‚Äúback in time‚Äù and spot changes and errors
Prepares you for collaborative projects and software development

‚Üí Knowing about version control is a very useful skill!

Commit message: every time you make a commit you must also write a short commit message

title: Version control (Github)

Terms (2)

Pull request: submitting contributions to a project
Branch: diverge from the main line of development and continue to do work without messing up this main line.

title: Web scraping basics
text:
Packages
Installing the necessary packages:

install.packages(c("rvest", "RSelenium", "robotstxt", "polite"))

Today and in the next sessions we will use:

rvest (Wickham, 2021), for scraping websites & RSelenium (Harrison, 2020), for browsing the web programmatically
robotstxt (Meissner and Ren, 2020), for checking permissions to scrape websites
polite (Perepolkin, 2019), for compliance with permissions to scrape websites

title: Web scraping basics
text:
Java

RSelenium needs Java to run

for the automation of scripts

You can download Java from https://www.java.com/en/download/

You have to restart open browsers after installing Java

title: Web scraping basics
text:
Chrome

Chrome is best suited for RSelenium and favoured by most developers
You can download Chrome from https://www.google.com/chrome/
However, Firefox is also fine!

title: Web scraping basics
text:
SelectorGadget

Can be added as an extension for Chrome

simplifies the selection process for web scraping
open source

You can search for SelectorGadget here: https://chrome.google.com/webstore/category/extensions
Alternative: ScrapeMate

works for both Chrome and Firefox
search ScrapeMate at https://addons.mozilla.org/ to add the extension on Firefox

title: Web scraping basics
text:
Legal Issues

Web scraping could be illegal!

it depends: Who is web scraping what sites? How is the scraping conducted? Under which jurisdiction?

The following represent possible illegal web scraping activities:

web scraping results in collapse of website (too many and large inquiries)
collecting (private) copyright data and use it for own gain (e.g., selling e-mail adresses)

title: Web scraping basics
text:
Ethical Issues

Web scraping could also be unethical!

again, it depends: Who, what, why, and how?

The following represent possible unethical web scraping activities:

not respecting restrictions set by the website administrator (e.g., robots.txt files)
collecting data in short time-intervals without need which is available to download via an API

title: Web scraping basics
text:
robots.txt Files

Most websites provide a so-called robots exclusion protocol

it includes information on what is allowed to scrape and at what speed
the information is stored within robots.txt files

the can be found via the websites URL: e.g., www.EXAMPLE.com/robots.txt


These rules are not binding, so you could scrape the website however you want.

BUT: legal and ethical issues!

title: Web scraping basics
text:
robots.txt Syntax

GeneralSyntaxExample



robots.txt files are easy to read and understand

we can make use of the robotstxt package





User-agent: Who is the protocol intended for?
Allow: What part of the website can be scraped?
Disallow: What part of the website is not allowed to be scraped?
Crawl-delay: How fast should we scrape the website?







The key always starts with capital letters and is followed by a colon.






User-agent:
Allow:
Disallow:
Crawl-delay:

title: Web scraping basics
text:
robots.txt Syntax

ExampleCode


Websites define the keys themselves:

*: protocol is targeted at everyone
/: full website can be scraped
/about/: this specific path is not allowed to be scraped
numeric values for Crawl-delay: are given in seconds




User-agent: *
Allow: /
Disallow: /about/
Crawl-delay: 10

title: Web scraping basics
text:
robots.txt Example

User-agent: googlebot
Allow: /

This websites‚Äô protocol is only for Google:

Google is allowed to scrape everything without any restrictions
No defined rule for anyone else

title: Web scraping basics
text:
robots.txt Example

ExampleMeaning



User-agent: googlebot
Disallow: /about/
Disallow: /history/
Crawl-delay: 60



This websites‚Äô protocol is only for Google:

Google is disallowed to scrape two specific paths
Only allowed to access at 60-seconds intervals
No defined rule for anyone else

title: Web scraping basics
text:
robots.txt Example

ExampleMeaning



User-agent: googlebot
Allow: /
Crawl-delay: 5

User-agent: bing
Disallow: /
  
User-agent: *
Allow: /companyinfo/



This websites‚Äô protocol is for different user agents:

Google is allowed to scrape everything in 60-second intervals
Bing is not allowed to scrape anything
Everyone else can scrape the section or page located at www.EXAMPLE.com/companyinfo/

title: Web scraping basics
text:
robots.txt Additional Information
The key Visit-time is less often used:

User-agent: *
Allow: /
Disallow: /impressum/
Visit-time: 00:00-06:00

robots.txt files can also include comments (preceded by #)

# This is a robots.txt file

User-agent: *
Allow: /
Disallow: /impressum/
Visit-time: 00:00-06:00 # visit website during night time in Germany

title: Web scraping basics
text:
robotstxt Package
The robotstxt package simplifies the process of checking website protocols:

we can check protocols from within R
we can check rules for specific paths and agents

The package has two main functions:

robotstxt: get the complete protocol
paths_allowed: check specific paths in the protocol

title: Web scraping basics
text:
robotstxt Package - robotstxt function

Info


Using the robotstxt function to get a protocol:

provide the base URL of a website within the domain argument as a string
most of the time no additional arguments needed ## Code


library(robotstxt)

robotstxt(
  domain = NULL,
  ...
)

title: Web scraping basics
section: Ethical Issues: Speed, Purpose, and Storage
text:
Ethical Issues: Speed, Purpose, and Storage

Speed: repeated, automatic web scraping in very short-time intervals can lead to overloading a website‚Äôs server

waiting time might be defined in protocol (Crawl-delay key)

Purpose: in the best case scenario, we have already a research question of hypothesis in mind before collecting (web scraping) data
Storage: often, we will need lots of storage place (big data)

data should be stored privately and safely

title: Web scraping basics
text:
HTML Basics
Websites include (usually) much more than only text, images, and links.
They include code for structure, style, and functionality which is interpreted by brwosers:

HTML: structure
CSS: style
e.g., JavaScript: functionality

title: Web scraping basics
text:
HTML Page Source
You can view the page source by right clicking and selecting View Page Source (Seitenquelltext anzeigen) or by the shortcut Ctrl + U (Strg + U).

title: Web scraping basics
text:
HTML DOM
You can view the structured source code (DOM - document object model) by right clicking and selecting Inspect (Untersuchen) or by the shortcut Fn + F12.

title: Web scraping basics
text:
Exercise 2

View the source page of a website

as plain source code and in DOM

Search for words or phrases in the source code

copy the word from the front-end page
then search using the shortcut: Ctrl + F (Strg + F)

title: Web scraping basics
Web scraping basics
Web scraping basics
Web scraping basics
Web scraping basics
Web scraping basics
Web scraping basics
text:
HTML - Syntax / Tags
Most elements have opening and closing tags:
<p> This is a paragraph. </p>
This is a paragraph.






The tag name, here p, defines structure of the element; the closing tag has a forward slash / before element name

title: Web scraping basics
text:
HTML - Syntax / Attributes
Elements might have attributes
<p>This is <strong id="count-sentence">one</strong> sentence.</p> 
This is one sentence.






Attributes are added to the opening tags (separated with a white space) - the id attribute has no visible effects - other attributes (e.g., style can have visible effects!)

title: Web scraping basics
text:
HTML - Syntax / Attributes
There can be more than one attribute in a single element:
<p>This is <strong class="count" id="count-sentence">one</strong> sentence.</p> 

<p>This is <strong class="count" id="count-paragraph">one</strong> paragraph.</p> 
This is one sentence.
This is one paragraph.






The same class attribute can apply to multiple elements (here: count)

title: Web scraping basics
text:
HTML - Links
Links are provided with the a (anchor) element
<p>Click <a href="https://www.uni-mannheim.de/">here</a> for the university's website.</p>
Click here for the university‚Äôs website.






href (hypertext reference) is a required attribute for this element - most attributes are optional, but some are required

title: Web scraping basics
text:
HTML - Links
Links can have titles:
<p>Click <a title="This text appears when visitors hover over the link"
href="https://www.uni-mannheim.de/">here</a> to get to the university's website.</p>
Click here to get to the university‚Äôs website.






Note


The title attribute is one of the optional attributes - becomes visible when hovered over.

title: Web scraping basics
Web scraping basics
Web scraping basics
text:
HTML - Containers
The <span> tag also defines a section, containing a part of an element

<p>This is an <`span` style="text-decoration: underline;">important paragraph<`/span`>, which
you must read carefully.<p>

This is an important paragraph, which you must read carefully.






Containers are useful in applying styles to sections

title: Web scraping basics
text:
CSS
CSS stands for cascading stylesheets

styles what is visible to visitors of the website:

text
images
links
‚Ä¶


CSS can be defined

inline, as an attribute of an element
internally, as a child element of the head element
externally, but then linked in the head element

title: Web scraping basics
text:
CSS Syntax

SelectorsDeclarationExamples


CSS syntax consists of one or more selectors, matching one or more HTML elements or attributes







syntax changes with selector type

elements and attributes are written as they are
classes are prefixed with a full stop
ids with a hashtag

the same rule can be defined for more than one element or attribute






CSS syntax consists of a declaration, with one or more properties and values







values are followed by a semicolon
property:value; pairs are separated by a white space






p {font-size:14px;}
h1 h2 {color:blue;}
.count {background-color:yellow;}
#count-sentence {color:red; font-size:16px;}

title: Web scraping basics
Web scraping basics
Web scraping basics
Web scraping basics
text:
CSS Inline
CSS rules can also be defined inline:
<p>This is <strong `style="color:blue;"`>one</strong> sentence.</p>

This is one sentence.








with the style attribute
does not require selector
applies only to that element

title: Web scraping basics
text:
Exercise 4

Provide some css to your HTML document created before

use internal or external style (not inline)
e.g., increase font size
change color
for more ideas: www.w3schools.com/css




Automated Data Collection | Spring 2024 | University of Mannheim

title: Web scraping basics
text:
robotstxt Package - paths_allowed function

InfoCode


We can use the paths_allowed function in order to check if we are allowed to scrape specific paths:

provide the base URL of a website within the domain argument as a string
Both path and bot are important arguments

attention to default values!

Output is either TRUE: We are allowed to scrape or FALSE: We are not allowed to scrape.




library(robotstxt)

paths_allowed(
  domain = "auto",
  paths = "/",
  bot = "*",
  ...
)

title: Web scraping basics
text:
robotstxt Package - paths_allowed
Let‚Äôs check different paths:

paths_allowed("https://www.uni-mannheim.de/")

[1] TRUE



paths_allowed("https://www.uni-mannheim.de/",
              paths = c("/studienangebot/", "/ausschreibungen/"))

[1] TRUE TRUE



paths_allowed("https://www.uni-mannheim.de/",
              paths = c("/studienangebot/", "/ausschreibungen/"),
              bot = c("googlebot", "bing"))

[1] TRUE TRUE

title: Web scraping basics
text:
Ethicas: Speed, Purpose, and Storage

Speed: repeated, automatic web scraping in very short-time intervals can lead to overloading a website‚Äôs server

waiting time might be defined in protocol (Crawl-delay key)

Purpose: in the best case scenario, we have already a research question of hypothesis in mind before collecting (web scraping) data
Storage: often, we will need lots of storage place (big data)

data should be stored privately and safely

title: Web scraping basics
text:
HTML Basics
If we want to web scrape, we need to refer to the source code:

scraping what is visible on the website
choosing only specific parts of a site (e.g., table)
also scraping ‚Äúinvisible‚Äù parts (e.g., URLs hidden under text)

title: Web scraping basics
text:
Exercise 3

Create a HTML file in RStudio:

File -> New File -> HTML File

Add to the HTML code from the slides
Click Preview to view your result

title: Web scraping basics
text:
CSS (cascading stylesheets)

styles what is visible to visitors of the website:

text, images, links
‚Ä¶


CSS can be defined

inline, as an attribute of an element
internally, as a child element of the head element
externally, but then linked in the head element

title: Web scraping static
text:
Static Pages: Overview (1)
We will use the rvest package to scrape data from static pages

Static pages display the same source code and content to all visitors

All visitors see the same page at a given URL
Each page has a different URL
e.g., wikipedia

title: Web scraping static
text:
Static Pages: Overview (2)
There are two main steps:

Download the source code from one or multiple pages to R

This is usually the only interaction with the page we need

Select the information we want to extract from the source code

title: Web scraping static
text:
Static Pages: rvest
Popular, ‚Äúproven‚Äù R package exclusively for web scraping by Hadley Wickham (part of the tidyverse)

Tutorials / documentation:

Package documentation
rvest overivew
Example by Julian Unkel

Can be easily combined with the polite package for ethical web scraping!

title: Web scraping static
text:
rvest: Get Source Code
The read_html function gets the source code of a page:

read_html("https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_Nations_organizations_by_location")

{html_document}
<html class="client-nojs vector-feature-language-in-header-enabled vector-feature-language-in-main-page-header-disabled vector-feature-sticky-header-disabled vector-feature-page-tools-pinned-disabled vector-feature-toc-pinned-clientpref-1 vector-feature-main-menu-pinned-disabled vector-feature-limited-width-clientpref-1 vector-feature-limited-width-content-enabled vector-feature-custom-font-size-clientpref-0 vector-feature-client-preferences-disabled vector-feature-client-prefs-pinned-disabled vector-feature-night-mode-disabled skin-theme-clientpref-day vector-toc-available" lang="en" dir="ltr">

[2] <body class="skin-vector skin-vector-search-vue mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ...









This is the first step of web scraping!
Now, we need to select the specific information we want to extract

title: Web scraping static
text:
rvest + polite: Get Source Code

Using the polite package simplifies ethical web scraping
Extracting the source coude is divided into two steps:

Checking the protocol
Extract source code if allowed

In addition, it allows us to:

Set a time interval for accessing the page (minimum what is specified in the protocol)
Introducing yourself to the website administrator while scraping

title: Web scraping static
text:
rvest + polite: Get Source Code

InfoCode


We can use to bow function to check the webpage‚Äôs protocol

for a specific URL




bow(
  url,
  ...
  )

title: Web scraping static
text:
rvest + polite: Get Source Code

InfoCode


We can use to bow function to check the webpage‚Äôs protocol

for a specific URL
for a specific agent







The argument user-agent provides the website administrator with information (e.g., name or contact details)






bow(
  url, 
  user_agent = "R √úbung", 
  ...
  )

title: Web scraping static
text:
rvest + polite: Get Source Code

InfoCode


We can use to bow function to check the webpage‚Äôs protocol

for a specific URL
for a specific agent
for crawl-delay







The argument delay cannot be smaller than in the protocol directive






bow(
  url, 
  user_agent = "R √úbung", 
  delay = 5 
  ...
  )

title: Web scraping static
text:
rvest + polite: Get Source Code

bow(
  "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_Nations_organizations_by_location", 
  user_agent = "R √úbung", 
  delay = 5
  )

<polite session> https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_Nations_organizations_by_location
    User-agent: R √úbung
    robots.txt: 456 rules are defined for 33 bots
   Crawl delay: 5 sec
  The path is scrapable for this user-agent

title: Web scraping static
text:
rvest + polite: Get Source Code

InfoCode


Now, we can use the scrape function to extract the source code:

for an object created with the bow function
it will only work if the results from the bow function are positive

meaning that we follow the webpage‚Äôs protocol


Pipe bow into scrape to avoid creating additional objects.



scrape(bow,
       ...
       )




bow(
  url,
  ...
  ) %>% 
  scrape()

title: Web scraping static
text:
rvest + polite: Get Source Code
No difference, no protocol against access:

read_html("https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_Nations_organizations_by_location")


bow("https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_Nations_organizations_by_location") %>% 
  scrape()

title: Web scraping static
text:
rvest + polite: Get Source Code
Now we see a difference as there is a protocol against access:

read_html("https://www.zeit.de/rezepte/suche/")

{html_document}
<html lang="de" class="no-js">
[1] <head>\n<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8 ...
[2] <body data-page-type="centerpage" data-template="" data-is-hp="false" dat ...



bow("https://www.zeit.de/rezepte/suche/") %>% 
  scrape()

NULL








Remember: We can check the protocol of webpages with the robotstxt package or by adding robots.txt to the URL (e.g., www.zeit.de/robots.txt)]

Check a specific path with the paths_allowed function

so, that it returns FALSE. Hint: use the information from the first task and look at the list of permissions

using the robotstxt function
are there any ethical issues?

title: Web scraping static
text:
rvest: html_elements

InfoCode


The function html_elements allows us to extract one ore multiple HTML elements from the source code we have downloaded.






html_element gets the first instance of a specific element, whereas html_elements gets all instances.






html_element(
             x, 
             css, 
             xpath)


html_elements(
              x, 
              css, 
              xpath)

title: Web scraping static
text:
rvest: html_elements

InfoCode


The function html_elements allows us to extract one ore multiple HTML elements from the source code we have downloaded.
We specify the HTML elements with a selector: CSS or XPATH.






During our course, we will use CSS, which is simplified by using Chrome and/or SelectorGadget (ScrapeMate).






html_element(
             x, 
             css, 
             xpath)


html_elements(
              x, 
              css, 
              xpath)

title: Web scraping static
text:
How to Find Selectors?
Finding the right selectors is the most important step for web scraping. We have different ways to do this:

We can inspect the source code / DOM

Not easy, time consuming, error-prone

We can use browser extensions such as SelectorGadget

Not always accurate, but easy and quicker

We can use Chrome

Good for selecting single elements

title: Web scraping static
section: How to Find Selectors With SelectorGadget?
text:
How to Find Selectors With SelectorGadget?

InfoExample


Finding selectors for hyperlinks on the Wikipedia page for UN organizations by location

Visit the webpage on your (Chrome ) browser
Activate the SelectorGadget extension
Click on any hyperlink








The clicked on element is highlighted in green
others are highlighted in yellow
SelectorGadget identifies the selector a

Now, click on one of the hyperlinks in the left pane (e.g., ‚ÄúMain page‚Äù) and one of the hyperlinks outside the tables on the main pane (e.g., ‚Äú1 Locations‚Äù) as we are only interested in the hyperlinks in the tables.

Other elements are not highlighted anymore
SelectorGadget identifies the selector .datasortkey a

title: Web scraping static
Web scraping static
text:
rvest: html_text

InfoCode


The function html_text extracts the text content of one or more HTML elements:

the elements chosen with the html_elements function








Two versions:

html_textreturns text with any space or line breaks around it
html_text2 returns plain text








html_text(x, trim = FALSE)

html_text2(x, preserve_nbsp = FALSE)

bow(
  url = "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_Nations_organizations_by_location") %>%
  scrape() %>%
  html_elements(css = ".datasortkey a") %>%

text:
rvest: html_attr & html_attrs

InfoCode


The function html_attrs extracts the attributes of one or more HTML elements:

the elements chosen with the html_elements function








Two versions:

singular extracts specified attribute

attribute is specified with its name, not CSS

plural extracts all attributes








html_attr(x, name, default = NA_character_)

html_attrs(x)

title: Web scraping static
text:
rvest: Extracting single variables
An approach to create a table by getting each variable separately (e.g., cities):

tibble(
  Cities =
  bow(
  url = "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_Nations_organizations_by_location") %>%
  scrape() %>%
  html_elements(
    css = "#mw-content-text > div.mw-parser-output > table:nth-child(7) > tbody > 
    tr > td:nth-child(2) > a") %>% 
  html_text()
)

# A tibble: 2 √ó 1
  Cities     
  <chr>      
1 Addis Ababa
2 Nairobi

title: Web scraping static
text:
rvest: Extracting single variables

source_code <- bow(
  url = "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_Nations_organizations_by_location") %>%
  scrape() 

tibble(
  Cities = source_code  %>% 
  html_elements(css = 
     "#mw-content-text > div.mw-parser-output > table:nth-child(7) > tbody > 
      tr > td:nth-child(2) > a") %>% 
  html_text()
)

title: Web scraping dynamic
text:
Crawling (Static) Pages: Overview
Most of the time, one page does not include all information we are interested in (e.g, it is spread over different pages of a website).
In this case, we can crawl over these different pages by using information on one of the website‚Äôs pages.
We can use for loops for crawling.

This can take a long time
We should even more think about ethical scraping!

title: Web scraping dynamic
text: Example: Bundeswahlleiterin - BTW 2021

text: Example: BTW 2021 - Land

text: Example: BTW 2021 - Results in tables

title: Web scraping dynamic
text: Example: Select links with SelectorGadget

title: Web scraping dynamic
text:
Example: Get links
First, we scrape the page that has all URLs:

links <- bow(url = "https://www.bundeswahlleiter.de/bundestagswahlen/2021/ergebnisse.html") %>%
        scrape() %>%
        html_elements(css = ".linklist__item+ .linklist__item a") %>% 
        html_attr("href") %>% 
        url_absolute(base = "https://www.bundeswahlleiter.de/bundestagswahlen/2021/")


head(links)

[1] "https://www.bundeswahlleiter.de/bundestagswahlen/2021/ergebnisse/bund-99/land-8.html" 
[2] "https://www.bundeswahlleiter.de/bundestagswahlen/2021/ergebnisse/bund-99/land-9.html" 
[3] "https://www.bundeswahlleiter.de/bundestagswahlen/2021/ergebnisse/bund-99/land-11.html"
[4] "https://www.bundeswahlleiter.de/bundestagswahlen/2021/ergebnisse/bund-99/land-12.html"
[5] "https://www.bundeswahlleiter.de/bundestagswahlen/2021/ergebnisse/bund-99/land-4.html" 
[6] "https://www.bundeswahlleiter.de/bundestagswahlen/2021/ergebnisse/bund-99/land-2.html"

title: Web scraping dynamic
section: Example: Get tables from each page
text:
Example: Get tables from each page
First, we create an empty list. We store our table later in that list.

list <- list ()

for (i in 1:length(links)) {
  
  page <- bow(links[i]) %>% scrape()
  
  list[[i]] <- page %>% 
          html_table() 
}

title: Web scraping dynamic
section: Example: Get tables from each page
text:
Example: Get tables from each page
Next, we use a for loop to iterate over each element in our list of links:

list <- list () 

for (i in 1:length(links)) { 
    
  page <- bow(links[i]) %>% scrape()

  list[[i]] <- page %>% 
        html_table() 

}

title: Web scraping dynamic
section: Example: Get tables from each page
text:
Example: Get tables from each page
Then, we politely (bow()) get the source code for each link (scrape()):

list <- list () 

for (i in 1:length(links)) { 
  
page <- bow(links[i]) %>% scrape()

list[[i]] <- page %>% 
        html_table() 

}

title: Web scraping dynamic
section: Example: Get tables from each page
text:
Example: Get tables from each page
Finally, we scrape the tables from each page with html_table() and store the results in our list:

list <- list () 

for (i in 1:length(links)) { 
  
page <- bow(links[i]) %>% scrape() 

list[[i]] <- page %>% 
        html_table()

}

title: Web scraping dynamic
text: Example: BTW 2021 - More links

title: Web scraping dynamic
text:
Overview
Dynamic pages display custom content.
Different visitors see different content on the same page - e.g., depending on their input (clicking, scrolling) - URL stays the same
For example, the Bundeswahlleiter (Federal Returining Officer) has dynamic elements on its website (e.g., selecting election year or voting results on subnational levels).
It is more difficult to scrape dynamic than static pages - we need one extra step - for this extra step, we are using the package RSelenium

title: Web scraping dynamic
text:
Dynamic Pages: Steps
Three main steps:

Use RSelenium to identify and select the desired elements of the page by clicking, searching, selecting from within RStudio
Get the source code

RSelenium downloads in XML format
we can use rvest to transform this into HTML

Extract the relevant information from the source code using the rvest package

this is the same process as for static pages

title: Web scraping dynamic
text:
Dynamic Pages: RSelenium
The RSelenium package integrates the Selenium 2.0 WebDriver into R. The package allows us to interact with

browsers on our device (e.g., open a browser and navigating to a page)
elements on a page (e.g., opening or clicking on a drop-down menu)

In case you are stuck on a particular problem, you can easily find help for only (e.g., stackoverflow, google, etc.) or more information in the vignette.

title: Web scraping dynamic
text:
Starting a Server With Firefox
We use the rsDriver function to start a server. This way we can control a browser of our choice from within R.

The function rsDriver creates the object driver and the web browser opens
You should avoid controlling this browser manually
You should avoid creating multiple servers
Note: We can start only one server per port


driver <- RSelenium::rsDriver(port = 0001L, 
                              browser = "firefox",
                              ...
                              )

title: Web scraping dynamic
text: Starting a Server With Firefox

title: Web scraping dynamic
text:
Starting a Server With Firefox
Next, we separate the client and server as different objects:

browser <- driver$client
server <- driver$server







rsDriver() creates a client and a server

our code primarily interacts with the client
we can think of the client as the browser itself; it has the class remoteDriver

title: Web scraping dynamic
text:
Navigate dynamic pages

browser$navigate(url = "https://www.bundeswahlleiter.de/bundestagswahlen/2021/ergebnisse.html")







navigate is a method and not a function

we cannot pipe (%>%) it into browser but have to use the dollar sign notation
it is optional to type the name of the url argument

title: Web scraping dynamic
text: Navigate dynamic pages

title: Web scraping dynamic
text:
Navigate dynamic pages
Go back to previous URL:

browser$goBack()

Go forward:

browser$goForward()

Refresh:

browser$refresh()

title: Web scraping dynamic
text:
Navigate dynamic pages
Get URL of current page:

browser$getCurrentUrl()

Get title of current page

browser$getTitle()

title: Web scraping dynamic
text:
Dynamic Pages: Close & Open Browser
We can close the browser without closing our session on the server:

browser$close()

And open a new browser without using the rsDriver function again, as the server is still running:

browser$open()

title: Web scraping dynamic
text:
Dynamic Pages: Get Page Source
Using the RSelenium package, we get the page source code the following way:

browser$getPageSource()[[1]]


Note: This method returns a list . The XML source is in the first item of the list. This is why we use [[1]] to access it.



This is similar to our bow() %>% scrape() process

title: Web scraping dynamic
text:
Dynamic Pages: Get Page Source
We can extract links combining methods and function from the RSelenium and the rvest package:

browser$getPageSource()[[1]] %>% 
        read_html() %>% 
        html_elements(css = ".linklist__item+ .linklist__item a") %>% 
        html_attr("href")

title: Web scraping dynamic
text:
Dynamic Pages: Find Elements
We can locate an element on the open browser using CSS selectors
There are also other selectors as

xpath
id
name
link text

title: Web scraping dynamic
section: Dynamic Pages: Find and Highlight Elements
text:
Dynamic Pages: Find and Highlight Elements

## navigate to page
browser$navigate(url = "https://www.bundeswahlleiter.de/bundestagswahlen/2021/ergebnisse.html")

## find and store element
selection <- browser$findElement(using = "css selector", value = ".dropdown__toggler")

## highlight element
selection$highlightElement()

Note: The highlighted element will flash for one or two seconds on the open browser.

text:

as_tibble(selKeys) %>%

title: Web scraping dynamic
text:
Dynamic Pages: Input
For example, we can scroll up and down a page from within R:

body <- browser$findElement(using = "css", value = "body")

body$sendKeysToElement(list(key = "page_down"))

title: Web scraping dynamic
text:
Dynamic Pages: Example Bundeswahlleiterin

Bundesl√§nder <- c("Baden-W√ºrttemberg",
                  "Bayern")
table <- list()

for (i in Bundesl√§nder){
browser$navigate(url = "https://www.bundeswahlleiter.de/bundestagswahlen/2021/ergebnisse/bund-99.html")
selection <- browser$findElement(using = "css selector", value = ".dropdown__toggler")
selection$clickElement()
dropdown <- browser$findElement(using = "link text", value = i)
dropdown$clickElement()
table[[i]] <- browser$getPageSource()[[1]] %>% 
        read_html() %>% 
        html_elements(css = "table.tablesaw:nth-child(2)") %>% 
  html_table()  
}

title: Interactive I: Create your first Shiny app
text:
Dashboards

Dashboards represent a tool for effective data visualization
They allow us to communicate information as intuitively as possible and can support data-driven decision making
We focus presenting our results and telling a story!
Dashboards are useful for science communication but also provide added value in other areas such as consulting, business, etc.

title: Interactive I: Create your first Shiny app
text:
Why Shiny apps?
Most importantly:

(Interactive) communication of scientific results
(Interactive) visualization of data sets

But there are many more use cases!

title: Interactive I: Create your first Shiny app
text: Shiny apps - User showcase

title: Interactive I: Create your first Shiny app
section: Key elements of a Shiny app
text:
Key elements of a Shiny app

UI (user interface):

Here, we can determine the ‚Äúlook‚Äù of our app.

Server:

Here, we define our functions

shinyApp():

Combines our UI and server parts.

title: Interactive I: Create your first Shiny app
text:
How to assemble these elements

set upuiservershinyApp()Output



library(shiny)
library(bslib)
library(tidyverse)

data <- readRDS("data/constituency_shapes_vote.RDS")




ui <- page_sidebar(
      title = "2017 German election data",
      sidebar = sidebar(
        selectInput(
          inputId = "parties", 
          label = "Choose a party", 
          choices = c("AfD", "CDU", "CSU", 
                      "Left" = "DIE LINKE", 
                      "FDP", 
                      "Greens" = "GR√úNE", 
                      "SPD"), 
          selected = "AfD"
        )
      ),
    
    plotOutput("histogram")
)




server <- function(input, output) {
  
  output$histogram <- renderPlot({
    
    data %>% 
      filter(party == input$parties) %>%
      ggplot() +
      geom_histogram(aes(x = vote_share),
                     binwidth = 2.5,
                     boundary = 0) +
      scale_x_continuous(labels = scales::percent_format(scale = 1), 
                         limits = c(0, 80)) +
      theme_minimal() +
      labs(y = "Count",
           x = "Vote share")
  })
}




shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server)

ReactivityStep 1Step 2Step 3


Reactivity is what makes your Shiny apps responsive. It lets the app instantly update itself whenever the user makes a change.
Garrett Grolemund, Understanding reactivity

text:
Building your own app

Get startedCustomizeWidgets



There are many great resources online. I recommend starting with the R Shiny documentation on how to get started and to build your own app:

https://shiny.posit.co/r/getstarted/shiny-basics/lesson1/index.html

In addition, the Mastering Shiny book by Hadley Wickham is great!

https://mastering-shiny.org/index.html

title: Interactive I: Create your first Shiny app
text:
How to publish your app

There are many ways. I find shinyapps.io the easiest.

Set up a free account at shinyapps.io

Follow only a few steps in this short tutorial. It includes:

Installing and loading the rsconnect package
Add your token from your shinyapps.io account to the rsconnect package once
Deploy your app via the Publish button while viewing the app

Organisation & Resources

Materials will be provided via the course website.
Communication via ILIAS. Make sure that you have access to the course on ILIAS and that emails that are sent over ILIAS are forwarded to the email account you check regularly
Weekly office hours before the course. Please make an appointment via e-mail!

title: Intro Session
text:
Course requirements

ParticipationAssignmentsTerm paper


To get out the most of this seminar, active participation and preparation is needed!
Check the readings, review the code (exercises), make sure that you understand the concepts, and ask questions!


Individual assignments during the semester (need to pass).
There will be 3 (short) assignments during the semester - one for each block. Here, you have to demonstrate that you can apply the concepts/code presented during the session on your own.


In a nutshell: Ask a question you‚Äôre curious about, collect relevant data, and analyze them with regard to your question using the techniques learned in this seminar.
The term paper can contain up to 4500 words (+/- 10%, excluding title page, references, and appendix). Deadline: 01.07.2024, 17:00. 100% of your grade.
In any case, I recommend to discuss your approach and ideas either via e-mail or during office hours!

Of course, you can always talk directly to me if you feel comfortable with the question. It is important to note that the University‚Äôs Equality and Diversity Office supports and advises you in cases of discrimination or sexual harassment. The responsible contact person in such a case is Dipl.-Psych. Ute Pfr√ºnder. She is trained to deal with such incidents and will keep everything strictly confidential. No action will be taken without your express consent.

text:
Plan for today
Input

R, R Studio, and basics
Data types & formats

Your turn: Short exercises

title: Intro to R
text:
R is a language and environment for statistical computing and graphics. Click here for more info
We refer to the basic functionalities of R as base R
We can extend these installing R packages from CRAN (The Comprehensive R Archive Network). For example, the tidyverse. This allows us to simplify the data analysis workflow.
BUT: It comes with a limited GUI (Graphical User Interface)

title: Intro to R
text: R GUI

title: Intro to R
text:
RStudio is the most popular IDE (Integretated Development Environment) for R.

IDEs enable syntax highlighting, auto-completion, or a better overview our created output.

Beyond these general benefits, R Studio provides us with

an integration of version control via Git and addins such as citr or styler
interfaces to other programming languages (e.g., Python via the reticulate package)

title: Intro to R
text: R Studio Interface

title: Intro to R
text: R Studio - Script editor

title: Intro to R
text: R Studio - Console

title: Intro to R
text: R Studio - Environment

title: Intro to R
text: R Studio - Files, Plots, Help, ‚Ä¶

title: Intro to R
text: R Studio - Options

title: Intro to R
text:
Using R as a calculator
The simplest application is to use R as a calculator:

1 + 1

[1] 2





1 / 10

[1] 0.1





2 * 2

[1] 4

title: Intro to R
text:
Commenting code
We can comment our code using the #. Input thereafter will not be executed as code.

# Addition
1 + 1

[1] 2





2 * 2 # 2 times 2 should equal four

[1] 4


Typically, we want to comment our code extensively for replicability and reusability.

title: Intro to R
text:
Functions
Functions are essential for our workflow in R. They take input(s) as argument, and produce output(s) depending on the input.

sqrt(100)

[1] 10

title: Intro to R
text:
Objects I
R is an object-oriented programming language.

Therefore, we can store single values, multiple values, character strings, etc. in an object.
We can assign a single value to an object using the assignment operator <-


# here we assign the numeric value 10 to the object x:
x <- 10

# we can do the same for a character string:
y <- "This is a character string"

title: Intro to R
text:
Objects II
We can also store the output of functions in objects:

# here, we calculate the square root of 100 
# and store it in a object called "result"
result <- sqrt(100)

Further, we can also do calculations with objects:

# here we add our two objects and store the result in z
z <- x + result

Finally, we can print the object to the console by typing its name:

# z should print the number 20 (10 + sqrt(10))
z

[1] 20

title: Intro to R
text:
Packages

Packages allow us to go beyond base R functionalities.
They consist of various functions that simplify tasks and provide documentation.



We can install packages from within R via CRAN:


# we need to install packages only once:
install.packages("stringr")

# however, we need to load the package every time we (re-)start R
library(stringr)

title: Intro to R
text:
Example: stringr

# lets load the stringr package:
library(stringr)

# using the help() function, we can inspect the documentation
help(stringr)

title: Intro to R
text:
Example: stringr
The stringr package provides us with multiple functions to manipulate strings.

# as an example, we create a fictitious actor ID from the Twitter API
string <- "id:twitter.com:207584738373"

# to match this ID with meta data, we only want to keep the numbers
# we can make use of the function str_replace()
# It needs these arguments: str_replace(string, pattern, replacement)
clean_ID <- str_replace(string, "id:twitter.com:", "")

# let's check if it worked:
clean_ID

[1] "207584738373"

title: Intro to R
text: tidyverse

title: Intro to R
text:
tidyverse vs.¬†base R
The tidyverse has become very popular among R users. It provides:

clean and tidy code (readability)
functions for typical data science tasks
a coherent ‚Äúgrammar‚Äù

BUT: it also introduces dependencies, and packages evolve.

title: Intro to R
text: Develop your own coding style

title: Intro to R
text:
It all depends on how

how &where data is stored


How: data types

Numeric values (integers & doubles)
Character strings
Logical values
Factors
‚Ä¶



Where: data formats

Vectors
Data frames/Tibbles
Lists
‚Ä¶

title: Intro to R
text:
Numeric values
There are two types in R: Integers (numbers without a decimal values) and doubles (numbers with decimal values)

# We place an L behind the value to be specific that it is an integer
x <- 10L

# using the typeof() function we can check the data type
typeof(x)

[1] "integer"



# create a double
z <- 10.55

# check data type
typeof(z)

[1] "double"



# is x numeric?
is.numeric(x)

[1] TRUE

title: Intro to R
text:
Character strings
A string represents a series of characters. Numbers and/or symbols can also be part of a string.

# we need to wrap the string into quotation marks

string <- "Hello"

# we can check the type using class()
class(string)

[1] "character"

# an example with numbers
ID <- "id:twitter.com:207584738373"

# check again
class(string)

[1] "character"

title: Intro to R
text:
Factors
We call data types that assume that their values are not continuous and have distinct categories factors.
Factors take numeric values or character strings as input and convert them into so-called levels:

# let's create an factor:
factor(1)

[1] 1
Levels: 1

title: Intro to R
text:
Logical values
They are either TRUE or FALSE (and also called Boolean values). We produce them by making logical requests:

1 > 2

[1] FALSE


We can also store logical values is objects:

logical <- 1 > 2

logical

[1] FALSE

title: Intro to R
text:
Logical operators

RelationalLogical



< less than
<= less than or equal to
> greater than
>= greater than or equal to
== exactly equal to
!= not equal to




& (AND)
| (OR)

title: Intro to R
text: Data formats

title: Intro to R
text:
Vector
We can create vectors by combining individual objects with the function c() (‚Äúconcatenating‚Äù):

# This works for numbers
numeric_vector <- c(1,2,3)

numeric_vector

[1] 1 2 3



# ... for characters
character_vector <- c("CDU", "CSU", "SPD")

character_vector

[1] "CDU" "CSU" "SPD"



# and for logical values
logical_vector <- c(TRUE, FALSE, FALSE)

logical_vector

[1]  TRUE FALSE FALSE

title: Intro to R
text:
Data frames
They are comparable to data sets as in Stata or SPSS

with n rows and k columns
and allow us to store variables of different classes.


# we create a data frame called df 
# using the function "data.frame()
df <- data.frame(
  party = c("CDU", "CSU", "SPD"),
  vote_share = c("27", "5", "13")
)

. .

df

  party vote_share
1   CDU         27
2   CSU          5
3   SPD         13

title: Intro to R
text:
Data frames
We can also check the dimensions, number of observations, and number of variables:

# dimensions
dim(df)

[1] 3 2

# number of observations
nrow(df)

[1] 3

# number of variables
ncol(df)

[1] 2

title: Intro to R
text:
Lists
We can combine any number of objects to a list:

# using the list() function
test_list <- list(numeric_vector,
                  character_vector)

test_list

[[1]]
[1] 1 2 3

[[2]]
[1] "CDU" "CSU" "SPD"

title: Intro to R
text:
Accessing and subsetting objects

Typically, we are not interested in all of the data
We want to access specific information
This works similar across different object types (vectors, data frames, lists, ‚Ä¶)


# Let's go back to our party vector:
party_vector <- c("CDU", "CSU", "SPD")

# we only want to access the first element
party_vector[1]

[1] "CDU"



# we can store this in a new object:
CDU <- party_vector[1]

title: Intro to R
text:
Accessing and subsetting data frames
We can select rows, columns, and specific elements. This follows the general logic:

data_frame[specify_row, specify_column]

Let‚Äôs try this:

# This is our data frame
df

  party vote_share
1   CDU         27
2   CSU          5
3   SPD         13

# Let's select only the first column
df[,1]

[1] "CDU" "CSU" "SPD"

title: Intro to R
text:
Accessing and subsetting data frames
We can also access individual variables using the $ sign:

df$party

[1] "CDU" "CSU" "SPD"


Alternatively, we can index by variable name:

df["party"]

  party
1   CDU
2   CSU
3   SPD


Or variable order:

df[1]

  party
1   CDU
2   CSU
3   SPD

title: Intro Session
text:
My plan & expectations

We are a rather large group. Maybe adaptation is needed during the semester.
Mix of lecture-style input, live coding, group exercises, and discussion.
Active participation in class and preparation
Willingness to invest time to learn a (new) programming language, look for solutions on your own, and keep trying

title: Tidyverse II: Transform, and visualize
text:
Reshape the data!

OverviewTo wideMutateTo long






head(afd, n = 2)

# A tibble: 2 √ó 7
  district_no district_type district_name group_type group_name  vote vote_share
  <chr>       <chr>         <chr>         <chr>      <chr>      <dbl>      <dbl>
1 001         Wahlkreis     Flensburg ‚Äì ‚Ä¶ Partei     AfD            1       15.0
2 001         Wahlkreis     Flensburg ‚Äì ‚Ä¶ Partei     AfD            2       15.3

afd_wide <- afd %>%
  pivot_wider(names_from = "vote", 
              names_prefix = "vote_share_",
              values_from = "vote_share")

head(afd_wide, n = 1)

# A tibble: 1 √ó 7
  district_no district_type district_name     group_type group_name vote_share_1
  <chr>       <chr>         <chr>             <chr>      <chr>             <dbl>
1 001         Wahlkreis     Flensburg ‚Äì Schl‚Ä¶ Partei     AfD                15.0
# ‚Ñπ 1 more variable: vote_share_2 <dbl>





afd_wide <- afd_wide %>% 
  mutate(Vote_share_diff = vote_share_1 - vote_share_2)

head(afd_wide)

# A tibble: 6 √ó 8
  district_no district_type district_name     group_type group_name vote_share_1
  <chr>       <chr>         <chr>             <chr>      <chr>             <dbl>
1 001         Wahlkreis     Flensburg ‚Äì Schl‚Ä¶ Partei     AfD                15.0
2 002         Wahlkreis     Nordfriesland ‚Äì ‚Ä¶ Partei     AfD                16.0
3 003         Wahlkreis     Steinburg ‚Äì Dith‚Ä¶ Partei     AfD                20.4
4 004         Wahlkreis     Rendsburg-Eckern‚Ä¶ Partei     AfD                15.4
5 005         Wahlkreis     Kiel              Partei     AfD                10.7
6 006         Wahlkreis     Pl√∂n ‚Äì Neum√ºnster Partei     AfD                17.8
# ‚Ñπ 2 more variables: vote_share_2 <dbl>, Vote_share_diff <dbl>





afd_diff <- afd_wide %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = !c(district_no:group_name), 
               names_to = "vote", 
               names_prefix = "vote_share_",
               values_to = "vote_share")

head(afd_diff)

# A tibble: 6 √ó 7
  district_no district_type district_name group_type group_name vote  vote_share

title: Tidyverse II: Transform, and visualize
text: The datasaurus dozen

title: Tidyverse II: Transform, and visualize
text:
What makes a great visualization?
Graphical excellence is the well-designed presentation of interesting data‚Äîa matter of substance, of statistics, and of design ‚Ä¶ [It] consists of complex ideas communicated with clarity, precision, and efficiency. ‚Ä¶ [It] is that which gives to the viewer the greatest number of ideas in the shortest time with the least ink in the smallest space ‚Ä¶ [It] is nearly always multivariate ‚Ä¶ And graphical excellence requires telling the truth about the data.¬†

Edward Tufte (1983). The Visual Display of Quantitative Information, p.¬†51.

Grammatical Layers

FoundationalCodeAdditional






ggplot(data = gapminder,
       mapping = aes(x = gdpPercap,
                           y = lifeExp,
                           color = continent)) +
  geom_point()

title: Tidyverse II: Transform, and visualize
text:
Building a ggplot step-by-step

PackagesCodePlot


Packages to reproduce the plots:

# library(tidyverse)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(gapminder)




ggplot(data = gapminder %>% filter(year==2007),
  aes(x = gdpPercap, 
      y = lifeExp,
  color = continent))

title: Tidyverse II: Transform, and visualize
text:
Adding a geometry: geom_point()

CodePlot



ggplot(data = gapminder %>% filter(year==2007),
  aes(x = gdpPercap, 
      y = lifeExp,
  color = continent)) +
  geom_point()

title: Tidyverse II: Transform, and visualize
text:
Adding a scale

CodePlot



ggplot(data = gapminder %>% filter(year==2007),
  aes(x = gdpPercap, y = lifeExp,
  color = continent)) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_x_log10()

title: Tidyverse II: Transform, and visualize
text:
Adding further geometries

CodePlot



ggplot(data = gapminder %>% filter(year==2007),
  aes(x = gdpPercap, y = lifeExp,
  color = continent)) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_x_log10() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm")

title: Tidyverse II: Transform, and visualize
text:
Add different color scale

CodePlot



ggplot(data = gapminder %>% filter(year==2007),
  aes(x = gdpPercap, 
      y = lifeExp,
  color = continent)) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_x_log10() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm") +
  scale_color_viridis_d()

title: Tidyverse II: Transform, and visualize
text:
Use facets

CodePlot



ggplot(data = gapminder %>% filter(year==2007),
  aes(x = gdpPercap, 
      y = lifeExp,
  color = continent)) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_x_log10() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm") +
  scale_color_viridis_d() +
  facet_wrap(vars(continent), ncol = 2)

title: Tidyverse II: Transform, and visualize
text:
Add titles, subtitles, etc.

CodePlot



ggplot(data = gapminder %>% filter(year==2007),
  aes(x = gdpPercap, 
      y = lifeExp,
  color = continent)) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_x_log10() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm") +
  scale_color_viridis_d() +
  facet_wrap(vars(continent), ncol = 2) +
  labs(x = "GDP per capita", 
       y = "Life expectancy",
       color = "Continent",
       title = "Wealth = Health?",
       subtitle = "gdpPercap/lifeExp",
       caption = "Gapminder dataset")

title: Tidyverse II: Transform, and visualize
text:
More geometries

CodePlot



ggplot(data = filter(gapminder, year %in% c(2007)),
aes(x = lifeExp,
fill = continent)) +
geom_histogram(binwidth = 5,
               color = "grey") +
scale_fill_viridis_d() +
facet_wrap(vars(continent), ncol = 2) +
guides(fill = "none")

title: Tidyverse II: Transform, and visualize
text:
More geometries

CodePlot



colors <- c("red", "orange", "yellow", "green", "blue")

ggplot(data = filter(gapminder, year %in% c(2007)),
  aes(x = continent,
      y = lifeExp,
      fill = continent)) +
  geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.5) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = colors) +
  guides(fill = "none")

title: Tidyverse II: Transform, and visualize
text:
More geometries

CodePlot



ggplot(gapminder, aes(x = year, 
                      y = lifeExp,
                      group = country)) +
  geom_line(alpha = 0.2, color="grey") +
  geom_line(data = gapminder %>% filter(country %in% c(
    "Germany",
    "India",
    "Rwanda")),
    lwd = 1) + # thicker line

Themes
Make use of existing themes:

There are many more! And you can even create your own theme!

ggthemes

ggplot(data = gapminder %>% filter(year==2007),

  geom_point() +
  ggthemes::theme_economist()

title: Tidyverse II: Transform, and visualize
text: theme()

title: Tidyverse II: Transform, and visualize
text:
How to learn theme() arguments?

There are 94 possible arguments for the theme() function
Many of them are very specific. E.g., axis.ticks.length.x.top
Best way: Trial and error. Practice makes (almost) perfect
Try the ggThemeAssist package
Documentation: Modify components of a theme and ggplot complete themes

title: Intro to Text-as-Data I: Concepts
text:
Coding



Import & Wrangle



Use the data on ILIAS: ‚Äúbtw_2025.rds‚Äù.
Create an East-West variable (0 if the election district is in Western Germany, 1 if in Eastern Germany). Hint: Use if_else() or case_when().







Visualize


1) Scatterplot: Show the relationship between the unemployment rate and AfD vote share at the district level. 2) Add color: The dots representing East and West German districts should have different colors. 3) Appearance: Add a title, change the theme, label the axes, ‚Ä¶ 4) Bonus: Can you plot this for each party, but keep it in one plot? Hint: Use facet_wrap()






Text-as-Data in R | Spring 2025 | University of Mannheim

title: Intro to Text-as-Data I: Concepts
text:
Practice: Coding



Import & Wrangle



Use the data on ILIAS: ‚Äúbtw_2025.rda‚Äù.
Create an East-West variable (0 if the election district is in Western Germany, 1 if in Eastern Germany). Hint: Use if_else() or case_when().







Visualize


1) Scatterplot: Show the relationship between the unemployment rate and AfD vote share at the district level. 2) Add color: The dots representing East and West German districts should have different colors. 3) Appearance: Add a title, change the theme, label the axes, ‚Ä¶ 4) Bonus: Can you plot this for each party, but keep it in one plot? Hint: Use facet_wrap()

title: Intro to Text-as-Data I: Concepts
text:
Text everywhere?
Many of our social and political interactions are textual:

Political positions and laws are written down üìù
(Political) Events are discussed üì∞
On- and offline communication üì£
History is recorded üìö

These interaction generare huge amounts of data. Analysis at scale has become viable only relatively recently.

title: Intro to Text-as-Data I: Concepts
text:
Group work
Up to 4 students:

Brainstorm 2-3 research questions
How can you operationalize your variables?
What might be suitable data to study these questions?
